Dear Ms. Trotter:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 28, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides, that the
person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The
documentation shall be completed not more than
30 days prior to the start of employment and every
12 months thereafter.
One of eight employees (an intern) did not have a DHHS
clearance.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
1

(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Two of eight employee records were non-compliant.
One employee did not have a performance evaluation after
completion of the probationary period.
One employee did not have an annual performance evaluation.
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following documentation of an
admission physical examination for each resident, unless an
earlier examination is medically indicated:
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 1 year prior to
admission or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after admission.
Two of three residents did not have a physical exam within 30
days after admission
(repeat violation)
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(a) Name, birth date, gender, race, height, weight, hair color,
eye color, identifying marks, religious preference and
school status.
(c ) A brief description of the resident’s preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state
at the time of admission.
(d) Name, address and marital status of parents or guardian,
if known.
(h) A brief description of the circumstances leading to the
2

need for care.
Two of three resident records were non-compliant.
One resident had no initial placement outline.
One resident’s initial placement outline was not completed
weeks after the time of admission.
R 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date
an initial treatment plan for each resident within 30
calendar days of admission.
Two of three ITPs were completed 4 and 6 days late.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date
an updated treatment plan for each resident at least once
every 90-calendar days following the initial treatment
plan.
Two of four UTPs were completed 2 and 13 days late.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
3

(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
One of three closed resident records did not contain any of
the required discharge information.
2.) The facility is in compliance will all ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCAN Contract Planned Discharge - Contact
2.10, pg 27 Contact shall include at least two home visits and at least one
successful phone contact per week to both the parent and child
for 30 calendar days following discharge to assist in re-
establishing family equilibrium.
Two of three records in non-compliance.
4

One resident had no documentation that aftercare services were
provided.
One resident was only visited once in the first 30 days after
discharge.
(repeat non-compliance)
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
During this licensing period, Girlstown has struggled to maintain a sufficient number of
direct care staff. Also five of seven staff were new to their positions in 2019. To
maintain the required staff-to-resident ratio, the facility has been utilizing clinical and
management staff to provide direct care. This month, there was a great deal of staff
turnover. A supervisor of direct care staff was terminated, a therapist resigned, the
former supervisor of direct care staff was re-hired and two new direct care staff were
hired.
I requested the facility submit an interim plan identifying who will be responsible for
providing therapy, writing ITPs/UTPs, and supervising/approving ITPs/UTPs until a
therapist is hired and trained. The person supervising/approving the reports cannot be
the same person writing them. Once Girlstown is fully staffed, I suggest all employee’s
adhere to their designated roles. If the case manager position needs to be versatile (ie,
to provide direct care at times), that should be included in the job description. If a new
therapist is hired, I recommend the therapist be the sole person responsible for writing
reports.
Personnel information for each intern should be organized and maintained separately
in its own file.
Continue using the discharge form developed by Girlstown that meets all of the
licensing rule requirements.
The child status section of updated treatment plans should assess and summarize
the resident’s behavioral/emotional functioning throughout the designated report
period.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Per R 400.4156 (3) (a) – Dates, persons contacted, type of contact, and place of
contact should be included in the updated treatment plan (social work contacts).
5

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The facility submitted one acceptable corrective action plan resulting from the
Renewal inspection of 2019 in which the following was cited:
R 400.4128 (3) Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training
R 400.4144 (2) (b) Admission health screening; physical examinations
R 400.4152 (a) (c) (d) (h) Initial documentation
RFCAN Contract 2.10, pg 27 Planned discharge – contact
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective
action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
